STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
November 18, 2020
Linda Needham
Lenawee County DHHS
1040 S. Winter Street
Adrian, MI 49221
RE: License #: CP460201242
Lenawee County DHHS
1040 S. Winter Street
Adrian, MI 49221
Dear Ms. Needham:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on (date). Due
to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and Modified
Implementation, Sustainability, and Exit Plan (MISEP) requirements, a written corrective
action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also
violations of the MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days
from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 For repeat violations, note why the previous plan failed.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (269) 337-5289.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Kari Muntean, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
22 Center Street
Ypsilanti, MI 48198
(734) 395-0920
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION

Services

Lansing, MI 48902

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
SRM 200 CHRI Access to Authorized Individuals, General
Three of five applicable employees completed their security awareness fingerprint
training late per a central office review.
REPEAT VIOLATION, Renewal Report 09/24/19, and corresponding CAP, 10/10/19,
as well as Interim Report 10/16/18, and corresponding CAP, 10/25/18. The agency
will need to report why the previous CAPs failed and how they will ensure
compliance.
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(b) Verification of education.
(d) Three references obtained from persons who are
unrelated to the staff person.
(e) A record of any convictions other than minor traffic
violations from either of the following:
(i) The Michigan state police or the equivalent state or
Canadian provincial law enforcement agency where the person
usually resides.
(ii) An entity accessing either Michigan state police
records or equivalent state or Canadian provincial law
enforcement agency where the person usually resides.
(b) One new volunteer file was found not to have documentation of education.
(d) One new intern file was found to be missing the three references. The agency
stated that the Office of Human Resources (OHR) should have completed the
references but OHR stated that they do not complete references for interns, and that
the agency must facilitate this.
(e) One new volunteer file was found to have a criminal clearance completed eight
months after hire.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
4

(c) A copy of the initial evaluation with written endorsement
by the borrowing agency that the evaluation is acceptable.
(d) A copy of the current reevaluation with written
endorsement by the borrowing agency that the evaluation is
acceptable.
(h) A copy of the current children's foster home license
application and children's foster home licensing transaction
record documents from the certifying agency.
(c)(d) Three of three borrowed bed files reviewed did not contain a written
endorsement on the initial evaluations and current reevaluations.
(h) One of three borrowed bed files reviewed did not contain a 3706 licensing
transaction record.
R 400.12403 Policy and procedures.
(2) The policies and procedures shall cover at least all of the
following areas:
(i) Service plans.
Two of six foster care files reviewed were found to have missing and late (beyond 30
days) caregiver signatures. REPEAT VIOLATION, Renewal Report 09/24/19, and
corresponding CAP, 10/10/19. The agency will need to report why the previous
CAP failed and how they will ensure compliance.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(4) If an emergency change in placement is necessary, then all
of the documentation required in subrules (2) and (3) of this rule
shall be in the child's record within 14 calendar days after the
change in placement.
Three of three foster care files reviewed for change of placement were found, at the
time of the inspection, to have missing DHHS 69 Action Summaries to record the
required discharge information. The forms were uploaded to MiSACWIS after the
inspection but were beyond the 14 calendar days. REPEAT VIOLATION, Renewal
Report 09/24/19, and corresponding CAP, 10/10/19, as well as Interim Report
10/16/18, and corresponding CAP, 10/25/18. The agency will need to report why
the previous CAPs failed and how they will ensure compliance.
R 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time.
An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and
parenting time that contains, at a minimum, all of the following:
5

(b) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster
child and the foster parent in the foster parent’s home at
least once every month.
One of six foster care files reviewed was found to have missed one monthly in-home
visit with the foster child.
R 400.12422 Foster care record.
(3) The record shall contain all of the following information:
(e) Change of placement documentation as required by R
400.12405.
One of four closed foster care files reviewed contained a DHHS 69 Action Summary
completed 11 days after the closure.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The
facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements except for the
following:
ISEP 6.12.a & b - Page 20 - Maximum Children in a Foster Home
Two of two applicable foster care files reviewed for placement exception requests
were found to have PERs submitted for approval after the child was placed in the
home. REPEAT VIOLATION, Renewal Report 09/24/19, and corresponding
CAP, 10/10/19, as well as Interim Report 10/16/18, and corresponding CAP,
10/25/18. The agency will need to report why the previous CAPs failed and
how they will ensure compliance.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional DHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included
in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
DHHS Policy FOM 801 – page 11-13 Medical Passports
One of six foster care files reviewed was found to be missing documentation that
the medical passports were provided at the time of placement for the 5/1/20 &
9/15/20 placements. REPEAT VIOLATION, Renewal Report 09/24/19, and
corresponding CAP, 10/10/19, as well as Interim Report 10/16/18, and
corresponding CAP, 10/25/18. The agency will need to report why the
previous CAPs failed and how they will ensure compliance.
6

DHHS Policy FOM 722-06H - Page 5 - CASEWORKER CONTACT CHILD IN
OUT-OF-HOME PLACEMENT
One of three applicable foster care files reviewed was found to be missing a
second face to face visit with the child in the second month after replacement.
DHHS Policy - FOM 722-06H - Page 10 – CASEWORKER CONTACT WITH
PARENT(S)/ GUARDIAN(S)
One of four applicable foster care files reviewed was found to be missing
documentation of a parental home visit during the second quarter. REPEAT
VIOLATION, Renewal Report 09/24/19, and corresponding CAP, 10/10/19. The
agency will need to report why the previous CAP failed and how they will
ensure compliance.
DHHS Policy FOM 722-06H p 15 TIMELY ENTRY OF CASEWORKER
CONTACTS
Three of six foster care files reviewed were found to have social work contacts that
were not entered timely (within the five days permitted). The contacts were
observed to have been entered between four and 86 days late. REPEAT
VIOLATION, Renewal Report 09/24/19, and corresponding CAP, 10/10/19, as
well as Interim Report 10/16/18, and corresponding CAP, 10/25/18. The
agency will need to report why the previous CAPs failed and how they will
ensure compliance.
DHHS Policy 722-06B - page 2-6 - Family Team Meetings
Five of six foster care files were found to be noncompliant with Family Team
Meetings. These files were found to have missing FTMs (four files), and/or were
missing 1105 FTM reports (two files), and/or had FTMs that were completed
beyond the 30 days prior to the service plan (two files). REPEAT VIOLATION,
Renewal Report 09/24/19, and corresponding CAP, 10/10/19, as well as
Interim Report 10/16/18, and corresponding CAP, 10/25/18. The agency will
need to report why the previous CAPs failed and how they will ensure
compliance.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
7

R 325 License Recommendation
The agency is advised to complete the summary section of the 3080 forms to ensure
complete and accurate documentation.
DHHS Policy - FOM 722-06H Page 1-3 – OVERVIEW and QUALITY VISIT
STANDARDS
The agency is advised to ensure that workers are thoroughly and sufficiently
covering all required components for documentation of quality visits.
R 403 Policy and procedures (2)(i) Service Plans
The agency is advised to ensure documentation of sending reports to parents and
their responses if they are somehow unable to return the signature page. There was
one file found to have sent the service plans to the mother, who responded via email
that she received them, but could not return the signed copy. The worker should
document this on the signature page of the plan as one would do if a parent refused
to sign, in order to document the occurrence.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
The agency is asked to ensure accuracy of their lists and to ensure that
information is correct prior to submitting for the inspection.
8

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
There was one incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period. The agency completed a thorough special evaluation of the foster
home and cited the violation appropriately. A corrective action plan was
implemented related to the violation. It appears the agency adequately addressed
the situation.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period. This corrective action plan, dated
11/18/19, was submitted in response to special investigation report 2019C0207042,
dated 11/05/19. The agency was cited for R 325 license recommendation as they
noted non-compliances related to safety but did not ensure the CAP addressed the
safety issues. This issue did not present itself again in this review among the special
evaluation and the reevaluations reviewed, therefore, it appears the agency is
following their CAP.
There are 13 violations in this inspection report compared to 25 in the last. This
shows significant improvement and compliance with the previous CAP. There are 8
repeat violations noted in this report for which the agency needs to focus on to
ensure they bring those areas into compliance.
The field analyst report noted no safety concerns, therefore, no follow up was
required.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on a
regular license.
November 18, 2020
________________________________________
Kari Muntean Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
9

November 18, 2020
________________________________________
Claudia Triestram Date
Area Manager
10
